A law of composition on a set $M$ is a map from $M \times M$ to $M$. It is characterized by the assignment $(a, b) \longmapsto a \cdot b$ for $(a, b) \in M \times M$, and in many cases, the image of a given pair $(a, b)$ is written as a "product" $a \cdot b$ or $ab$.
An element of a set is an object belonging to a set.
Does the concept of a/an Law of Composition need to be defined for a definition of a/an Element of a Set to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation:
The concept of an 'Element of a Set' is defined as any object that belongs to a set. This definition is self-contained and does not rely on any operations or relationships between the elements of the set beyond their mere membership in the set.

On the other hand, a 'Law of Composition' involves a rule for combining two elements of a set to produce another element of the same set. This concept is related to operations within the set but does not influence the basic definition of what it means for an object to be an element of a set.

Therefore, the definition of an 'Element of a Set' does not require the concept of a 'Law of Composition' to be meaningful. The existence or definition of a law of composition is irrelevant to whether an object can be considered an element of a set.
